metadata.case_name: Indian Molasses Co. Private Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

facts.text: John Bruce Richard Harvey was the Managing Director of the assessee Company in 1948, had served for 13 years, due to retire at age 55 on September 20, 1955.
Agreement existed by which the Company was under obligation to provide pension to Harvey after retirement.
On September 16, 1948, Company executed Trust Deed in favour of three trustees, paid £8,208-19-0 (Rs. 1,09,643), undertook to pay annually Rs. 4,364 (£326-14 sh.) for six consecutive years.

Trustees undertook to hold sums upon trust to take out deferred annuity policy with Norwich Union Life Insurance Society in trustees' name on Harvey's life, £720 per annum payable to Harvey for life from superannuation.
Trust deed provided alternative: deferred joint life policy for Harvey and Mrs. Harvey, £558-1-0 per annum joint lives/survivor; if Harvey dies before 55, £611-12-0 to Mrs. Harvey.
If Harvey dies before 55, trustees to purchase annuity for Mrs. Harvey.
Trustees took out policy on January 12, 1949 (question refers to 13th January, 1949).
Policy benefits: £563-5-8 p.a. if both alive on Sept 20,1955; £720 if Mrs. Harvey dies before leaving Harvey surviving; £645 if Harvey dies before leaving Mrs. Harvey surviving.
Special provision: Trustees entitled to surrender annuity on Sept 20,1955 for £10,169 with notice.
Clause III: If both nominees die before Option Anniversary, return of all premiums without interest.
Clause IV: Surrender value before/after Option Anniversary: return of premiums less first year's or 5% of capital sum, lesser amount.
Assessee Company paid initial sum and yearly premia for some years before Harvey died.
In assessment years 1949-50, 1950-51, 1951-52, 1952-53, claimed deduction of sums under s.10(2)(xv).
Claim disallowed by Income-tax Officer, Appellate Assistant Commissioner, Appellate Tribunal.
Tribunal held no expenditure at all, as money could revert via resulting trust if both Harveys die before 1955.
Tribunal referred question to Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 15 of 1954.
High Court answered question in negative on December 21, 1955.
Special leave granted by Supreme Court on November 9, 1956.
High Court noted two contingencies for reversion: both die before 1955; omission if Mrs. Harvey dies first (but policy covered).
Harvey died before the accounting years ended, but after some premia paid.

legal_issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, and on a true construction of the Trust Deed dated 16th September 1948 and the Policy dated 13th January 1949, the payments made by the assessee Company constitute expenditure within the meaning of that word in section 10(2)(xv) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922, in respect of which a claim for deduction can be made, subject to other conditions.

petitioner_arguments.text: Payment of pension is expenditure of revenue character; lump sum to rid of recurring pension liability also revenue.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: English cases like Hancock v. General Reversionary; Ch. IX-B of the Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Payments were actually made, expenditure in dictionary meaning; insurance expenditure not contingent as probabilities actuarially calculated.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Joseph v. Law Integrity Insurance; Prudential Insurance

respondent_arguments.text: Expenditure means laying out for accrued liability, not contingent; arrangement is setting apart for contingent liability till real.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Atherton v. British Insulated; Allahabad Bank Ltd. v. CIT

respondent_arguments.text: No expenditure in fact; possibility of resulting trust, money could revert to company.

court_reasoning.text: Question limited to whether payments were 'expenditure'; expenditure means paid out or away irretrievably, not set apart for contingency.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Money could revert to company via surrender or return of premiums if both Harveys die before 1955; liability contingent, not merely depending on contingency.

court_reasoning.text: Distinction between contingent liability and payment depending on contingency; here liability itself contingent as Harvey might not reach retirement.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No irrevocable payment; dominion over funds via trustees till 1955.

court_reasoning.text: English cases to be read with caution; under s.10(2)(xv), must be paying out wholly/exclusively for business, not capital/personal.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Pension to Mrs. Harvey not necessarily for business; but even for Harvey, not spent irretrievably.

holdings.text: Payments do not constitute 'expenditure' under s.10(2)(xv) as money not paid out irretrievably; possibility of reversion via resulting trust.

precedents_cited.case_name: Allahabad Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Different facts; contributions on trust failed leading to resulting trust, but here not clear-cut.

precedents_cited.case_name: Atherton v. British Insulated and Helsby Cables, Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Sum to pension fund nucleus not deductible as capital/uncertain.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hancock v. General Reversionary and Investment Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Lump sum to buy out existing pension liability deductible; here no accrued liability.
Invalidity fund uncertain, not deductible unlike certain pension.

precedents_cited.case_name: Smith v. Incorporated Council of Law Reporting
Morgan Crucible Co. Ltd. v. Commissioners of Inland Revenue
precedents_cited.relevance: Policy acquiring asset for company not deductible.

precedents_cited.case_name: Anglo-Persian Oil Co. Ltd. v. Dale
precedents_cited.relevance: Lump sum closing periodic payments revenue.

precedents_cited.case_name: Alexander Howard & Co. Ltd. v. Bentley
precedents_cited.relevance: Redemption of non-business annuity not deductible.

precedents_cited.case_name: Southern Railway of Peru Ltd. v. Owen
precedents_cited.relevance: Contingent retirement compensation not fully deductible without present value estimate.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Defines allowable expenditure: not capital/personal, wholly/exclusively for business.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitioner relied on for pension schemes, but court held not applicable as claim not under these provisions.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held that the payments did not constitute 'expenditure' under s.10(2)(xv) as they were not irretrievably paid out but subject to contingencies allowing reversion to the company; question correctly answered negatively by High Court.

key_quotes.text: 'Expenditure is thus what is paid out or away and is something which is gone irretrievably.'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines core test for deductibility under s.10(2)(xv).

key_quotes.text: In our opinion, the question was correctly answered by the Calcutta High Court.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Affirms High Court's negative answer, dismissing appeal.

key_quotes.text: The liability was contingent and not merely depending upon a contingency.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes nature of liability, rejecting deductibility.
